articles.headline: A Ransacked Endowment at New York City Opera
articles.snippet: Mismanagement at the now-bankrupt New York City Opera led it to raid its endowment to pay off its huge deficits.
articles.abstract: Mismanagement at the now-bankrupt New York City Opera led it to raid its endowment to pay off its huge deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: A fundamental premise of successful investing is “sell high, buy low.” So what explains the New York City Opera board’s decision to do the opposite?

articles.headline: Netanyahu Takes a Lonely Stance Denouncing Iran
articles.snippet: As Western powers prepare for talks on Iran’s nuclear program, an increasingly isolated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu continues his push for stronger action.
articles.abstract: As Western powers prepare for talks on Iran’s nuclear program, an increasingly isolated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu continues his push for stronger action.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the son of a historian, often complains to his inner circle that “people have a historical memory that goes back to breakfast.”

articles.headline: Finance Class on the Web, for Students of All Ages
articles.snippet: The 10 video lectures, which will be offered free, bring the graduate-level class of a Stanford finance professor to the general public.
articles.abstract: The 10 video lectures, which will be offered free, bring the graduate-level class of a Stanford finance professor to the general public.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, a master class available to everyone would reveal all the secrets to retirement planning, telling you how much to save, where to invest and what to do when the stock market crashes.

articles.headline: An Alliance in Media Petitions Justices
articles.snippet: An alliance of media groups says the Internet start-up Aereo is violating copyright law, but some analysts suggested the case was not ripe for Supreme Court review.
articles.abstract: An alliance of media groups says the Internet start-up Aereo is violating copyright law, but some analysts suggested the case was not ripe for Supreme Court review.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest television broadcasters are collectively asking for the Supreme Court’s support in their quest to stop Aereo, a small Internet start-up that threatens some of the underpinnings of the TV business.

articles.headline: Strapped In, but Still at Risk
articles.snippet: Though the number of deaths of children in car seats has declined, about three out of every four seats are still installed improperly, and it remains a vexing safety issue.
articles.abstract: Though the number of deaths of children in car seats has declined, about three out of every four seats are still installed improperly, and it remains a vexing safety issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAITHERSBURG, Md. — For more than two hours, Xiaopeng Li struggled to securely install two rear-facing car seats for his young children in his Toyota Sienna minivan.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Steinberg and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Airlines Cash In on Every Inch, Even the Jammed Bins Overhead
articles.snippet: The battle of the bins, that preflight scrum over carry-on space, has become something else for airlines: the business of the bins, with priority given to those who pay.
articles.abstract: The battle of the bins, that preflight scrum over carry-on space, has become something else for airlines: the business of the bins, with priority given to those who pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: A frosted cake. A 10-gallon hat. A car muffler.

articles.headline: For Safety in Reactors, Company Thinks Small
articles.snippet: A nuclear engineer has an idea to avoid disasters like the one that befell the Fukushima reactors in Japan in 2011: build very small reactors.
articles.abstract: A nuclear engineer has an idea to avoid disasters like the one that befell the Fukushima reactors in Japan in 2011: build very small reactors.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORVALLIS, Ore. — Jose N. Reyes has a surefire way to make certain that in case of accident, his nuclear reactor is surrounded by plenty of cold water: install it at the bottom of a giant swimming pool.

articles.headline: 2 States Plan 2-Tier System for Balloting
articles.snippet: Barred by the Supreme Court from requiring proof of citizenship for federal elections, Arizona and Kansas are planning to use a separate set of ballots for state and local races, which could decrease turnout.
articles.abstract: Barred by the Supreme Court from requiring proof of citizenship for federal elections, Arizona and Kansas are planning to use a separate set of ballots for state and local races, which could decrease turnout.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Barred by the Supreme Court from requiring proof of citizenship for federal elections, Arizona is complying — but setting up a separate registration system for local and state elections that will demand such proof.
articles.byline: By Fernanda Santos and John Eligon

articles.headline: When the Stock Price Hides Trouble
articles.snippet: Experts in corporate finance say that stock price, commonly used in setting pay, is imperfect as a gauge of managers’ ability to create value.
articles.abstract: Experts in corporate finance say that stock price, commonly used in setting pay, is imperfect as a gauge of managers’ ability to create value.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN a company receives criticism about its executive pay practices, a typical defense is to cite a rising stock price as justification of its pay. If total shareholder return is up, the theory goes, stockholders have no right to complain about what might otherwise look like outsize pay at their companies.

articles.headline: The Soaring Cost of a Simple Breath
articles.snippet: The high price of commonly used medications for conditions like asthma contributes heavily to health care costs and certainly causes more widespread anguish.
articles.abstract: The high price of commonly used medications for conditions like asthma contributes heavily to health care costs and certainly causes more widespread anguish.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The kitchen counter in the home of the Hayes family is scattered with the inhalers, sprays and bottles of pills that have allowed Hannah, 13, and her sister, Abby, 10, to excel at dance and gymnastics despite a horrific pollen season that has set off asthma attacks, leaving the girls struggling to breathe.

articles.headline: Riding Out the Political Storm
articles.snippet: Investment strategists say it’s likely that long-term investors who stick to a well-thought-out plan can ride out awkward periods like the current conflict in Washington with few ill effects.
articles.abstract: Investment strategists say it’s likely that long-term investors who stick to a well-thought-out plan can ride out awkward periods like the current conflict in Washington with few ill effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market began the week in a funk and ended in subdued celebration as apparent progress in the debt-ceiling impasse seemed to confirm the Wall Street consensus that dysfunction in Washington won’t lead to a debt default or set off a global cataclysm.

articles.headline: G.O.P.’s Hopes to Take Senate Are Dimming
articles.snippet: Republicans are being forced to explain why they are not to blame for the government shutdown, while Tea Party activists pose an insurgent threat.
articles.abstract: Republicans are being forced to explain why they are not to blame for the government shutdown, while Tea Party activists pose an insurgent threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Next year was supposed to be a prime opportunity for Republicans to retake the Senate. And for a while, everything seemed to be breaking their way: a wave of Democratic retirements, a fluke in the electoral map that put a large number of races in states that President Obama lost, a strong farm team of conservative Senate hopefuls from the House.

articles.headline: From the Start, Signs of Trouble at Health Portal
articles.snippet: Interviews and an examination of confidential documents point to a series of missteps — financial, technical and managerial — that led to the troubles with the new online insurance marketplace.
articles.abstract: Interviews and an examination of confidential documents point to a series of missteps — financial, technical and managerial — that led to the troubles with the new online insurance marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March, Henry Chao, the chief digital architect for the Obama administration’s new online insurance marketplace, told industry executives that he was deeply worried about the Web site’s debut. “Let’s just make sure it’s not a third-world experience,” he told them.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear, Sharon LaFraniere and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Family Man One Day, Rebel Fighter the Next
articles.snippet: Thousands of men who once held ordinary jobs in Syria have turned into part-time fighters, leaving their refugee families to return to the war.
articles.abstract: Thousands of men who once held ordinary jobs in Syria have turned into part-time fighters, leaving their refugee families to return to the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMTHA, Jordan — The Syrian rebel leader was sitting comfortably on a cushion at his home here recently, his wife and children filling the rooms with conversation and laughter. Then one day he shaved off his beard and slipped back into Syria, where he leads a rebel brigade.

articles.headline: World Leaders Press the U.S. on Fiscal Crisis
articles.snippet: The fiscal problems of the United States dominated meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington this weekend.
articles.abstract: The fiscal problems of the United States dominated meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington this weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders at World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings on Sunday pleaded, warned and cajoled: the United States must raise its debt ceiling and reopen its government or risk “massive disruption the world over,” as Christine Lagarde, the fund’s managing director, put it.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Philadelphia Newspaper’s Owners at War
articles.snippet: The battle at The Philadelphia Inquirer may seem like one more bit of denouement for an industry on the wane, but it spotlights a fight for the soul of both an institution and a city.
articles.abstract: The battle at The Philadelphia Inquirer may seem like one more bit of denouement for an industry on the wane, but it spotlights a fight for the soul of both an institution and a city.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a group of wealthy, politically connected local businessmen bought The Philadelphia Inquirer in April 2012, there were concerns that they would use its influence to further their own interests, ruining what was left of a once remarkable American newspaper.

articles.headline: Bolstering a Phone’s Defenses Against Breaches
articles.snippet: To help ward off corporate data breaches, Lookout is using its app to slip under the door of enterprises via the employees who regularly bring their personal devices to work.
articles.abstract: To help ward off corporate data breaches, Lookout is using its app to slip under the door of enterprises via the employees who regularly bring their personal devices to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — From Lookout’s headquarters here, the view extends west from the Bay Bridge to the Golden Gate, but its employees — mostly 20-something engineers in T-shirts and jeans — seem too preoccupied with the world’s nastiest new threats to take it in.

articles.headline: Viral Content With a Liberal Bent
articles.snippet: Upworthy.com, a site that hopes to edify visitors on a variety of social issues, may be cracking the code on how to bring them in.
articles.abstract: Upworthy.com, a site that hopes to edify visitors on a variety of social issues, may be cracking the code on how to bring them in.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is conventional wisdom about what kind of material will go viral on the Internet: celebrity slide shows, lists like 10 tips for losing belly fat, and quirky kitten antics.

articles.headline: Fall TV Season Delivers a Mixed Bag in Prime Time
articles.snippet: The networks have experienced a slight improvement in prime-time viewing this fall, but the landscape is still treacherous for new shows, several of which have been pulled after just two episodes.
articles.abstract: The networks have experienced a slight improvement in prime-time viewing this fall, but the landscape is still treacherous for new shows, several of which have been pulled after just two episodes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three weeks into the new television season, network executives have drawn some initial conclusions.

articles.headline: Privacy Fears Grow as Cities Increase Surveillance
articles.snippet: A program in Oakland, Calif., is one of the latest and most contentious examples of cities using big data technology, and federal dollars, for routine law enforcement.
articles.abstract: A program in Oakland, Calif., is one of the latest and most contentious examples of cities using big data technology, and federal dollars, for routine law enforcement.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Federal grants of $7 million awarded to this city were meant largely to help thwart terror attacks at its bustling port. But instead, the money is going to a police initiative that will collect and analyze reams of surveillance data from around town — from gunshot-detection sensors in the barrios of East Oakland to license plate readers mounted on police cars patrolling the city’s upscale hills.

articles.headline: Patients Mired in Costly Credit From Doctors
articles.snippet: Some doctors and dentists offer older patients a way to pay for costly procedures not covered by Medicare, but the plans’ high interest rates can strain the finances of people on fixed incomes.
articles.abstract: Some doctors and dentists offer older patients a way to pay for costly procedures not covered by Medicare, but the plans’ high interest rates can strain the finances of people on fixed incomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dentist set to work, tapping and probing, then put down his tools and delivered the news. His patient, Patricia Gannon, needed a partial denture. The cost: more than $5,700.

articles.headline: A Leaner Times Aims for Global Growth
articles.snippet: After shedding outside holdings, The New York Times Company this week will introduce The International New York Times and, later, new subscription, video and consumer initiatives.
articles.abstract: After shedding outside holdings, The New York Times Company this week will introduce The International New York Times and, later, new subscription, video and consumer initiatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: While some newspaper companies have spent recent years shifting their emphasis to other types of investments like television, The New York Times Company has taken a different path. It has been selling off its peripheral assets and concentrating on its flagship newspaper and Web site.

articles.headline: Legal Bills Rising, Cohen Is Said to Plan Art Sales
articles.snippet: Sotheby’s will sell two major Andy Warhol paintings and a canvas by Gerhard Richter owned by the billionaire hedge-fund manager Steven A. Cohen.
articles.abstract: Sotheby’s will sell two major Andy Warhol paintings and a canvas by Gerhard Richter owned by the billionaire hedge-fund manager Steven A. Cohen.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent months, as his legal troubles have deepened, the billionaire hedge-fund manager Steven A. Cohen has sold stocks to meet withdrawal requests from skittish investors.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Carol Vogel

articles.headline: In India’s Politics, Jail Time Is a Badge of Honor
articles.snippet: A growing urbanized middle class wants politicians facing charges driven from the system, but tribal voters see some, like Kameshwar Baitha, as heroes.
articles.abstract: A growing urbanized middle class wants politicians facing charges driven from the system, but tribal voters see some, like Kameshwar Baitha, as heroes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALTENGANJ, India — When he decided to run for a parliamentary seat from this impoverished, and mainly low-caste constituency in northeast India, Kameshwar Baitha made no effort to sugarcoat his criminal record.

articles.headline: Economists Clash on Theory, but Will Still Share the Nobel
articles.snippet: The work of the professors, Eugene F. Fama, Lars Peter Hansen and Robert J. Shiller, shows that stock prices tend to follow established rules in the long term.
articles.abstract: The work of the professors, Eugene F. Fama, Lars Peter Hansen and Robert J. Shiller, shows that stock prices tend to follow established rules in the long term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The economist Robert J. Shiller in 2005 described the rapid rise of housing prices as a bubble and warned that prices could fall by 40 percent.
